article:
In biochemistry, a 'dimer' is a macromolecular complex formed by two, usually
non-covalently bound, macromolecules like proteins or nucleic acids. It is a
quaternary structure of a protein.

A homo-dimer would be formed by two identical molecules (process called
'homodimerization'). A hetero-dimer would be formed by two different
macromolecules (process called 'heterodimerization').

Most dimers in biochemistry are not connected by covalent bonds. An example of a
non-covalent heterodimer would be the enzyme reverse transcriptase, which is
composed of two different amino acid chains. An
exception is dimers that are linked by disulfide bridges such as the homodimeric
protein NEMO.

Some proteins contain specialized domains to ensure dimerization
(dimerization domains).
